features.popup:
Ring Mountain ‚Äî Petroglyph Rock

PCN Petroglyphs PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition (predates Coast Miwok) ‚Äî found on Coast Miwok ancestral land
The most famous Bay Area rock art site. ~30 boulders with PCN carvings on chlorite blueschist ‚Äî metamorphic rock from an ancient subduction zone. Circular and ovoid grooves with raised nucleated centers, estimated 5,000-8,000 years old. CA-MRN-442. The only known rock art in Marin County. BARARA conservation effort (1993-1997) installed barriers against vandalism. Mortar holes and artifacts dated to ~2,400 years BP confirm long habitation.
üìñ Anderson (2006); Gillette (2011) UC Berkeley dissertation; Bay Nature; BARARA; Marin County Open Space
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Ring Mountain #2

PCN Petroglyphs PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Coast Miwok (Huimen) ancestral land
Additional PCN elements on a second boulder cluster at lower elevation (488 ft). Same tradition as Petroglyph Rock above.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Gillette (2011)
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

San Marin PCN Site

PCN Petroglyphs PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Coast Miwok (Omiomi) ancestral land
PCN petroglyphs survive in the San Marin area of Novato. Part of the Coast Range PCN tradition extending from Oregon border to Santa Barbara.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Gillette (2011)
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Canyon Trail Park ‚Äî El Cerrito

PCN Petroglyphs & Cupules PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Ohlone (Huchiun) ancestral land
~200 individual petroglyph elements including PCNs, cupules, and grooves on a chlorite blueschist boulder beside Baxter Creek. CA-CCO-152. First recorded 1949 by Squire. 20+ bedrock mortars and 175+ cupules. Excavations by Cal State Hayward/BARARA recovered cultural materials. City of El Cerrito approved conservation proposal to create a Native American Interpretive Park. Estimated 4,000-5,000 years old.
üìñ O‚ÄôBrien et al. (2005) SCA Proceedings; Marymor (2003) ARARA; Gillette (1998); East Bay Hill People
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Mira Vista Park ‚Äî Richmond

Cupule Complex (possible PCN)
Cultural affiliation: Pre-contact tradition ‚Äî found on Ohlone (Huchiun) ancestral land
10 bedrock mortars and 60+ cupules on a chlorite blueschist boulder near Baxter Creek. Same geological substrate as Canyon Trail Park PCN site 0.4 miles south.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Parkman (1986)

Alvarado Park ‚Äî Richmond

PCN Petroglyphs & Cupules PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Ohlone (Huchiun) ancestral land
2 bedrock mortars, 275+ cupules, and 2 confirmed PCNs on a chlorite blueschist outcropping on Wildcat Creek. The highest cupule density of any known Bay Area site.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Gillette (2011)
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Wildcat Creek Cupule Rock

Cupule Complex
Cultural affiliation: Pre-contact tradition ‚Äî found on Ohlone (Huchiun) ancestral land
20+ cupules and incising on a blueschist boulder in the middle of Wildcat Creek. Possible association with fishing rituals ‚Äî the boulder's position in the creek at a narrow point mirrors Pomo rock art placement patterns.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Bardell photographs

Stromer Spring ‚Äî Ohlone Wilderness

PCN Petroglyphs & Cupules PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Ohlone (Taunan) ancestral land
25 bedrock mortars, numerous cupules, and PCN-style petroglyphs at 2,023 ft elevation above Lake Del Valle. Requires a 2-mile hike with 1,200-ft climb from Del Valle's western shore. A major rock art site in the Ohlone backcountry.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Gillette (2011)
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Upper Crow Creek PCN

PCN Petroglyph (confirmed) PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Ohlone (Seunen) ancestral land
3 bedrock mortars and a confirmed PCN element. ‚ÄúThis sure looks like a Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated petroglyph to us.‚Äù
üìñ East Bay Hill People
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Black Hills Trail ‚Äî possible PCN

Possible PCN PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition (possible) ‚Äî found on Bay Miwok (Volvon) ancestral land
Three bedrock mortars, a possible PCN, and a grinding slick at 1,520 ft. ‚ÄúPecked curvilinear nucleated petroglyphs are not supposed to occur in Contra Costa County. We're not so sure.‚Äù
üìñ East Bay Hill People
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Possible PCN ‚Äî Brushy Peak area

Possible PCN PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition (possible) ‚Äî found on Bay Miwok (Ssaoam) ancestral land
Possible PCN element at 1,045 ft. Unusual because most Bay Area PCNs occur on schist, but this one appears on sandstone.
üìñ East Bay Hill People
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Evergreen Valley Cupule Rock

Cupules & possible PCN PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Ohlone (Santa Ysabel) ancestral land
32+ cupules on Silver Creek. CA-SCL-63. ‚ÄúThere are PCNs on this rock too, but we didn't notice any‚Äù ‚Äî later confirmed by stylistic analysis.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; A Stylistic Analysis of the Rock Art of Santa Clara County
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

CCo-434 ‚Äî Los Vaqueros Rock Art Complex

Polychrome Pictographs
Cultural affiliation: Bay Miwok (Volvon)
Nearly 50 separate prehistoric loci within a 3km-long series of massive sandstone outcrops containing caves, rockshelters, and overhanging ledges. Polychrome pictographs, bedrock mortars, dietary remains, obsidian/chert/quartzite tools, quartz crystals, and hematite loaves (pigment for pictographs). Obsidian hydration shows bimodal occupation. Virtually all obsidian from Napa Valley source (~60 miles).
üìñ Bramlette (1988); Eidsness (1986); SSU Anthropological Studies Center

Live Oak Campground ‚Äî Mt. Diablo pictograph cave

Pictograph Cave
Cultural affiliation: Bay Miwok (Volvon)
28 bedrock mortar milling station with a nearby pictograph cave of probable historic origin. One of the highest habitation sites in Volvon territory. Ancient trails converge near Curry Point.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Mt. Diablo Interpretive Association

Elephant Rock ‚Äî Mt. Diablo

Cupule Petroglyphs
Cultural affiliation: Bay Miwok (Volvon)
One bedrock mortar, cupules, and carved markings. May have been a ‚Äúprayer‚Äù site. See Parkman (1986) ‚ÄúCupule Petroglyphs in the Diablo Range.‚Äù
üìñ Parkman (1986) J. California & Great Basin Anthropology; East Bay Hill People

Rock City ‚Äî Mt. Diablo

Cupule Petroglyphs & Incisions
Cultural affiliation: Bay Miwok (Volvon)
13 bedrock mortars, grinding slick, cupules, and incisions. Deep, well-worn mortars indicating long habitation.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Mt. Diablo State Park

Chitactac-Adams Heritage County Park

Petroglyphs & Bedrock Mortars
Cultural affiliation: Ohlone (Mutsun)
75 bedrock mortars and a petroglyph at a restored Ohlone village site. BARARA members participate in conservation. Interpretive park with pathways. ‚ÄúStay on the pathway and no daylighting!‚Äù
üìñ Santa Clara County Parks; BARARA

Circle of Circles ‚Äî Morgan Hill

Ceremonial Rock Circles & Cupules
Cultural affiliation: Ohlone (Matalan)
Two bedrock mortars, five cupules, and at least eight rock circles atop a small hill. Archaeological evidence suggests 6,000 years old. Likely a ceremonial site.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Bardell photographs

Lynch Canyon Rancher Petroglyph Rock

Petroglyphs (some modern)
Cultural affiliation: Patwin (Suisun)
13 bedrock mortars and a petroglyph panel on mortar rock. Includes both ancient and modern (rancher-era) carvings. Near headwaters of North Fork of Lynch Creek.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Solano Land Trust

Cloverdale Petroglyph Boulder

PCN Petroglyphs & Cupules PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Southern Pomo ancestral land
PCN elements and cupules on a boulder along the Russian River near Cloverdale. Part of the Coast Range PCN tradition. Exact location not publicized to protect the site.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Hedges (1983) ‚ÄúThe Cloverdale Petroglyphs‚Äù Rock Art Papers; Gillette (2011)
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Yorkville Petroglyphs

Petroglyphs (pre-Pomo)
Cultural affiliation: Unknown pre-Pomo people
Large boulder near Yorkville covered with ancient petroglyphs that are distinctly different from known Pomo petroglyphs in Willits and Lake County, suggesting a much earlier origin predating the Pomo occupation of Anderson Valley.
üìñ Anderson Valley Advertiser; Mendocino County Historical Society

UC Hopland Research & Extension Center

PCN Petroglyphs & Cupules PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Hopland Pomo (Sh√≥qowa) ancestral land
Five boulders or clusters of boulders with PCN markings and cupules across 5,300 acres of the HREC. The subject of Donna Lee Gillette's seminal UC Berkeley dissertation on the PCN tradition. Over 30 identified prehistoric sites with 3,000+ catalogued artifacts. On Sh√≥qowa and Hopland Pomo ancestral land.
üìñ Gillette (2011) UC Berkeley dissertation; UC ANR Hopland REC
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Frog Woman Rock ‚Äî Hopland

Sacred Monolith (Pomo)
Cultural affiliation: Pomo (Hopland Band)
California Registered Historical Landmark No. 549. Sacred monolith revered by Pomo people as the home of Frog Woman, consort of Coyote. ‚ÄúA solemn witness that will forever be a local symbol of our indigenous collective conscience, strength, and perseverance.‚Äù Plaque placed 2023 by Tribal Historic Preservation Office of the Hopland Band of Pomo Indians.
üìñ CalTrans Historical Landmark; Hopland Band of Pomo Indians THPO

Lakeport area PCN / Baby Rocks

PCN Petroglyphs ‚Äî ‚ÄúBaby Rocks‚Äù PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî documented in Pomo ethnographic context (Eastern Pomo)
Ethnographically documented PCN/cupule boulders known as ‚ÄúBaby Rocks‚Äù in Pomo territory. Used in fertility rituals: a childless woman would fast for four days then visit the rock alone to commune with spirits of unborn children believed to dwell within. Deep grooves, cups, and PCNs present on horizontal and sloping surfaces. Part of the broader Coast Range PCN tradition.
üìñ Heizer (1953) ‚ÄúSacred Baby-Rocks‚Äù; Loeb (1926) Pomo Folkways; Hedges (1983); Gillette (2011)
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Knight's Valley Petroglyph Site

PCN / Baby Rock PCN TRADITION ¬∑ pre-contact ¬∑ est. 3,000-8,000 BP
‚ö† Cultural note: The PCN (Pecked Curvilinear Nucleated) tradition predates the tribal boundaries known from the contact era. These carvings span the entire California Coast Range from Oregon to Santa Barbara, crossing many later tribal territories. They were likely created by earlier Hokan or Penutian-speaking peoples. Attribution to any single post-contact tribe would be inaccurate.
Found on: Pre-contact PCN tradition ‚Äî found on Wappo / Southern Pomo border
PCN/cupule boulder in Knight's Valley, Sonoma County. Referenced in Loeb and Barrett ethnographies as one of the Pomo ‚Äúbaby rock‚Äù localities with deep grooves, cups, and PCN elements.
üìñ Barrett (1952); Loeb (1926); Gillette (2011)
Explore PCN Rock Art ‚Üí

Spyrock Petroglyph Site ‚Äî Eel River Canyon

Complex Petroglyphs (6 styles)
Cultural affiliation: Eel River Athapaskan (Wailaki) / earlier peoples
Rediscovered in 1982 by a state forester after being first found in 1913 by a US Government engineer. Provided the first evidence of complex rock art boulders in the western United States. Two panels with elaborate, multiple superimposed elements representing six discrete styles. Associated with a major village: three housepits, midden, abundant lithics. CA-TRI-1.
üìñ Spyrock, California Wikipedia; Mendocino/Trinity County archaeological records

Petroglyph Point ‚Äî Lava Beds NM

Petroglyphs & Pictographs (5,000+)
Cultural affiliation: Modoc people and predecessors
One of the largest panels of Native American rock art in the United States. Over 5,000 individual carvings on a tuff cliff face that was once an island in Tule Lake. Both carved petroglyphs and painted pictographs. Predominantly geometric/abstract patterns rather than figurative ‚Äî unusual for western rock art. Center of a Modoc creation story. Geometric patterns match household items from nearby Nightfire Island dated to 5,000 years ago. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places (1975). Some images may be 6,000+ years old.
üìñ NPS Lava Beds National Monument; Petroglyph Point Arch. Site NRHP (1975); Lee & Hyder, UCLA/UCSB

Monte Bello ‚Äî headwaters of Stevens Creek

Cupule Complex
Cultural affiliation: Ohlone (Olpen)
12 bedrock mortars and 64+ cupules (14 on one rock, 50+ on another) at 2,240 ft elevation. The proximity of cupule rocks to water sources is well-documented throughout the region.
üìñ East Bay Hill People; Joel's South Bay discoveries

ALA-60 ‚Äî Castro Valley

Cupule Complex (ancient)
Cultural affiliation: Ohlone (Yrgin)
44 bedrock mortars and 182 cupules. CA-ALA-60. E. Breck Parkman suggests this may be one of the oldest acorn processing sites in the Bay Area ‚Äî cultural material here has been dated to ~4,000 years BP.
üìñ Parkman; East Bay Hill People

Sulphur Spring ‚Äî 18 cupule rock

Cupule Complex
Cultural affiliation: Bay Miwok (Ssaoam)
18 cupule rock, 5 bedrock mortars, and a grinding slick. See Parkman (1986) ‚ÄúCupule Petroglyphs in the Diablo Range.‚Äù
üìñ Parkman (1986); East Bay Hill People

Painted Rock ‚Äî Carrizo Plain (La Piedra Pintada)

Polychrome Pictographs (3,000+ years)
Cultural affiliation: Chumash / Yokuts / Salinan (shared use over millennia)
Massive horseshoe-shaped marine sandstone formation, 250 feet across and 45 feet high, within the Carrizo Plain National Monument near Soda Lake. Interior adorned with pictographs by Chumash, Yokuts, AND Salinan peoples over millennia. Red, black, white, yellow, green, and blue pigments applied with rodent-tail hair brushes and finger painting. Chumash occupied the plain from ~2000 BCE until drought ~600 CE; Yokuts then moved in from the San Joaquin Valley. Yokuts motifs tend toward large colorful figures; Chumash toward small circular mandalas and complex panels. Bedrock mortars and cupules also present. Still used for ceremonies today by Native communities. Severely damaged by vandalism: a shotgun blast in the 1920s destroyed a major pictograph; settler names carved over art since 1908. Now protected within the National Monument (2001). Access by reservation only, seasonal closures March-May.
üìñ BLM Carrizo Plain NM; Cal Poly San Luis Obispo Special Collections; Wikipedia; Atlas Obscura; Clewlow 1978

Painted Rock ‚Äî Tule River Reservation (CA-TUL-19)

Polychrome Pictographs ‚Äî ‚ÄúHairy Man‚Äù site
Cultural affiliation: Yokuts (Wukchumni / Yowlumne) ‚Äî Tule River Indian Tribe
Sacred Yokuts rockshelter on the Tule River Indian Reservation near Porterville, immediately adjacent to the Tule River. Contains the only known ‚ÄúBigfoot‚Äù pictograph in all of western North America. The dominant image is Mayak datat (‚ÄúHairy Man‚Äù) ‚Äî a 2.6m √ó 1.9m polychrome figure in red, black, and white, representing an 8.5-foot creature with long hair and large eyes with tear lines (because Hairy Man is sad, per the creation story). Uniquely, an entire Bigfoot FAMILY is depicted: male, female (1.8m, red), and child (1.2m, red). Additional pictographs: coyote, beaver, bear, frog, caterpillar, centipede, eagle, condor, lizard, humans. Also includes bedrock mortars, pitted boulders, and village midden. Archaeologist David Whitley proposed a ‚Äúman in bear costume‚Äù interpretation; Yokuts elders firmly disagreed, maintaining it depicts a real creature from their creation stories. Paintings estimated 500-1,000 years old (Clewlow 1978 estimates ~500 CE to 1200 CE). First recorded by Hoffman (1882) and Merriam (1903).
üìñ Kathy Moskowitz Strain (2012) ‚ÄúMayak Datat‚Äù in Relict Hominoid Inquiry, ISU; Tule River Indian Tribe; Hoffman 1882; Merriam 1903; Clewlow 1978; Latta 1949

Rocky Hill Pictographs ‚Äî Exeter (CA-TUL-326/998)

Pictographs + Bedrock Mortars
Cultural affiliation: Yokuts (Foothill Yokuts ‚Äî Wukchumni)
Extensive pictograph panels with bedrock mortars directly beneath ‚Äî a repeated association at Yokuts sites. Located near a Yokuts village. At least 100+ deep bedrock mortars. Recent archaeoacoustics research (Alarc√≥n-Jim√©nez et al., 2024) examined the sound properties of this site and other south-central California rock art locations, finding that pictograph placement may be connected to acoustic landscapes ‚Äî sites with unusual echo or resonance properties. Some Yokuts cupule petroglyphs here were also painted (Hector 2009).
üìñ Whitley 2006; Gorden 2009; Hector 2009; Robinson 2011; Alarc√≥n-Jim√©nez et al. 2024

Rocky Hill Pictographs ‚Äî Porterville (CA-TUL-326)

Pictographs + BRM Village
Cultural affiliation: Yokuts (Foothill Yokuts ‚Äî Wukchumni/Koyeti)
Yokuts pictograph site associated with a large village. Similar to the Exeter Rocky Hill in having bedrock mortars in close proximity to painted panels. Part of a pattern of foothill Yokuts sites combining domestic (milling) and ceremonial (rock art) functions in the same location ‚Äî comparable to Tomo Kahni in the Tehachapis. Suggests rock art was integrated into daily village life, not separate from it.
üìñ Whitley 2006; Clewlow 1978; Hector 2009

Tomo Kahni ‚Äî Kawaiisu/Yokuts Ceremonial Site

Pictographs + Village Complex (CA-KER-508)
Cultural affiliation: Kawaiisu (Numic) / Yokuts trade connections
Major rock art and village complex in the Tehachapi Mountains. Multiple site numbers (CA-KER-508, -230, -4445H). Repeat the association between bedrock mortar stations and pictograph panels seen at Yokuts sites throughout the southern Sierra foothills. Associated with the Kawaiisu people (Numic speakers) who traded extensively with Yokuts of the valley floor. Now a State Historic Park with guided tours only. Contains pictographs in red, black, and white in sandstone rockshelters overlooking the Tehachapi Valley.
üìñ Whitley 2006; CA State Parks Tomo Kahni; Robinson 2011

Southern Sierra Pictograph Caves ‚Äî Foothill Yokuts

Pictographs (scattered caves)
Cultural affiliation: Foothill Yokuts (Wukchumni) / Monache / Kawaiisu
In remote areas of the southern Sierra Nevada foothills on the southeast side of the San Joaquin Valley, pictograph galleries are found in sandstone caves and beneath rock overhangs. Created by the Patwisha (Balwisha) Monache, Wukchumni Yokuts, and Kawaiisu, who traded with Tulumne and Yowlumne Yokuts of the valley floor. Art ranges from simple geometric petroglyphs to complex multicolor images of animals and daily life. Some researchers attribute the imagery to shamanic practice; others see artisans expressing creativity. The foothills between 2,000-4,000 ft elevation contain many undocumented sites.
üìñ BSA High Adventure Indian Lore; Southern Sierra pictograph surveys
